nexu.seoDescription: How ZIC stabilized Nexu's AntiFraud chain and reduced scoring delays, improving conversion by 12-18% during peak hours.
nexu.title: Nexu — stabilizing AntiFraud chain and reducing scoring delays
nexu.subtitle: How Integration ZIC eliminated AntiFraud chain failures and reduced route time from 14-20s to 8-11s without changing business logic.

challenge.title: Challenge
challenge.intro: At Nexu, the highest traffic occurred during 16:30–20:00 windows, when applications increased by 2.4–3.1×.
challenge.problemsIntro: Main failures occurred in the external verification chain:
problems: KRD service (Krajowy Rejestr Długów) responded unevenly: 1.2–5.4 seconds, creating "gaps" in flows.
BIG InfoMonitor AntiFraud process was blocked if BIG InfoMonitor delayed more than 3 seconds.
ScoreGateQueue accumulated 800–1200 applications, waiting for a complete data set.
Repeated requests to KRD and BIG gave 3–5× load during peak hours.
Conversion dropped because the average route time "entry → scoring" grew to 14–20 seconds.

solution.title: Solution
solution.intro: ZIC was integrated as a layer between external bureaus and Nexu's AntiFraud modules, without changing their business logic.
items: Normalization of KRD/BIG delays: ZIC did not trigger retries while the first request was active.
Centralization of retry logic: a single retry model, instead of each adapter duplicating its own.
Isolation of AntiFraud chain: timeout of one bureau no longer blocked the rest of the data.
Optimization of ScoreGateQueue: applications no longer waited for a "full package" when one service hung.
Reduction of traffic "dusting" when multiple adapters simultaneously triggered retry.

results.title: Results
items: Time to scoring: 14–20 s → 8–11 s
KRD/BIG retry requests: 3–5× → 1×
ScoreGate queues: 800–1200 → <250
AntiFraud blocking: eliminated
Peak hour conversion: +12–18%
Scoring logic: unchanged.

ukraineMfi.seoDescription: How ZIC stabilized UBKI, PVBKI, and AntiFraud for a Ukrainian MFI, reducing application losses from 18-26% to 2-5%.
ukraineMfi.title: Ukrainian MFI — stabilizing UBKI, PVBKI, and AntiFraud
ukraineMfi.subtitle: How Integration ZIC eliminated dead integrations and reduced scoring time from 17-25s to 9-13s without changing business logic.

challenge.title: Challenge
challenge.intro: During peak hours, the flow was broken by four critical nodes:
problems: UBKI: Delays jumped to 5 seconds. The adapter triggered 4–7 repeated calls, increasing load and direct overpayment for each request.
PVBKI: Service hung in pending status, provoking call duplication and cost growth during peak hours.
Internal Fraud Engine: Queues grew to 900–1400 events when UBKI/PVBKI slowly returned responses. Queue-blocking crashed the entire fan-in.
Internal ScoreEngine: The "entry → scoring" route stretched to 17–25 seconds, applications dropped out. Dead integrations reached 8–12%: statuses did not return, the flow broke.

solution.title: Solution
solution.intro: ZIC was introduced on top of existing services, without changes to their business logic:
items: Normalized UBKI/PVBKI: 1 call instead of 3–6, removed overpayment.
Introduced response cache to avoid duplicate requests.
Moved retry to a centralized mechanism, suppressing the retry avalanche.
Isolated AntiFraud from unstable credit bureaus, so queues would not block scoring.
Optimized the path to ScoreEngine, removing dependency on slow nodes.
Eliminated "dead integrations": state-machine recovery after partial responses.

results.title: Results
items: Credit bureau timeouts: decreased by 50%
Dead integrations: 8–12% → <1%
BKI retry calls: 4–7 → 1
AntiFraud queue: 900–1400 → 200–350
Time to scoring: 17–25 s → 9–13 s
Application losses: 18–26% → 2–5%
Scoring logic: unchanged.

agrotep.seoDescription: How Agrotep transitioned to microservices architecture and stabilized logistics integrations, reducing GPS queues from 18-25k to less than 2k.
agrotep.title: Agrotep — transition to microservices architecture and logistics integration stabilization
agrotep.subtitle: How Agrotep moved from monolithic architecture to microservices with stable integration layer, reducing GPS queues by 90% and ERP delays from 20-40 minutes to 1-3 minutes.

challenge.title: Challenge
challenge.intro: Agrotep works with a constant data flow from warehouse systems, GPS trackers, carriers, and ERP.
challenge.problemsIntro: The old monolithic system could not handle load in two critical zones:
problems: Transport tracking: GPS packets arrived at varying frequencies: from 5 to 90 seconds, the monolith could not process them in time, data went into queues up to 18–25 thousand records.

Carrier integrations: External APIs worked unstably: response time 1.2–4.8 seconds, some callbacks did not arrive, repeated requests created duplication in orders. At peak, this gave up to 14% false statuses in the chain "route creation → confirmation → actual delivery".
ERP chain: ERP waited for a full data package until transport status was updated. This blocked document formation for 20–40 minutes.

solution.title: Solution
solution.intro: The company transitioned to microservices architecture with a stable integration layer between systems.
items: GPS flow moved to a separate service with Kafka buffering.
Implemented data normalization service from carriers (unification of 5 different APIs).
Added retry model with duplication protection.
Implemented callback router for recovering delivery of lost statuses.
ERP receives events through queues, does not wait for the entire chain.
Implemented health monitor for all integrations.

results.title: Results
items: GPS queues: 18–25k → <2k
Transport status delay: 5–90 s → 3–7 s
False statuses in carriers: 14% → 1.5–2%
ERP delays in documents: 20–40 min → 1–3 min
Lost callbacks: decreased by ~85%

about.title: About Zardan Systems
about.headerDescription: Founded in 2018 in the United Kingdom, Zardan Systems is an engineering company specializing in integration solutions for the financial sector. Our expertise lies in high-load lending and scoring processes, where decision speed and stability under load are critical.

originTransformation.title: Origin & Transformation
originTransformation.p1: Zardan Systems was founded in 2018 in the United Kingdom as an engineering company specializing in integration solutions for the financial sector. Initially, the company focused on developing services for transaction processing and integrating external risk providers for European fintech companies.
originTransformation.p2: From 2020, the company focused on high-load lending and scoring processes, where decision speed and stability under load are critical. During this period, the team developed its own approach to flow orchestration and optimization of integrations with external services (credit bureaus, fraud detection, scoring engines). This approach later became the foundation of the ZIC product — Zardan Integration Core.
originTransformation.p3: Since 2021, Zardan Systems has been working with Central and Eastern European markets, including Polish digital credit platforms requiring integration with BIK, AntiFraud, and complex fan-in/fan-out processes, as well as Ukrainian MFIs operating with UBKI, PVBKI, internal AntiFraud systems, and unstable adapters.
originTransformation.p4: In 2022–2024, the company focused on the ZIC product, which brought enterprise integration practices to the fast lending segment, where there is no room for delays, duplicates, or hung adapters. Today, Zardan Systems is a small specialized engineering team with British jurisdiction and expertise in two niches: credit scoring and financial flow integrations.

capability.title: Capability
capability.p1: Zardan Systems designs, implements, and maintains integration frameworks and automation layers for enterprise infrastructures. Our core expertise lies in two specialized niches: credit scoring and financial flow integrations, where we ensure high-load processes remain stable, fast, and reliable.
capability.p2: The company applies architectural rigor, strict development standards, and measurable KPIs in every delivery. Each integration follows a clear sequence: requirement analysis, architecture definition, implementation, validation, and operational transfer. Our ZIC product brings enterprise-grade integration practices to fast lending environments, eliminating delays, duplicates, and adapter failures.
capability.p3: Beyond financial services, we also deliver integration projects in adjacent sectors including logistics, ERP systems, and event-driven systems for GPS and delivery services. Our goal is sustainable automation, where every process is traceable, every dependency documented, and every outcome verifiable.

operatingPrinciples.title: Operating Principles
operatingPrinciples.p1: We approach integration as an engineering discipline, not a service. Each system we design must be stable under load, transparent in execution, and predictable in maintenance.
operatingPrinciples.p2: Our processes emphasize auditability, accountability, and control. Documentation, monitoring, and performance baselines are established for every solution deployed.
operatingPrinciples.p3: Zardan Systems operates under principles of precision, verification, and reliability — ensuring that each delivered system enhances operational integrity and long-term scalability.

serviceRegions.title: Service Regions
serviceRegions.p1: The company provides services primarily across the European Union and the United Kingdom, with strong focus on Central and Eastern European markets since 2021. Our key directions include Polish digital credit platforms requiring integration with BIK, AntiFraud, and complex fan-in/fan-out processes, as well as Ukrainian MFIs working with UBKI, PVBKI, internal AntiFraud systems, and unstable adapters.
serviceRegions.p2: We also deliver integration projects in adjacent sectors including logistics, ERP systems, and event-driven systems for GPS and delivery services. Our development continues to focus on strengthening cooperation with European financial sectors through standardized integration frameworks and the ZIC product, which brings enterprise integration practices to fast lending environments.
